In a shocking twist of events, Charlotte is found lifeless in her kitchen, felled by a stun gun, and it's up to seasoned Detective Winston to unravel the mystery, with prime suspects being Letti and Annie, who is Asian,.
  
 

  
 

  Winston lit up a fresh cigarette, the inky night a silent observer as he reviewed Charlotte's file. It wasn't a pleasant read - Charlotte was hardly a pleasant individual. A chunk of the file was dedicated to dozens of threatening messages Charlotte had sent to Annie, each one more chilling than the last. It also documented instances where Charlotte had been physically and verbally abusive towards Annie; hitting her in fits of rage and screaming profanities in her face. 
  
 

  As he finished the last report, a woman - a shivering woman - approached him. Annie, the local chauffeur, the singular and exclusive mode of transportation for Charlotte...the woman he had planned to interview next. She was scheduled to pick Charlotte up on the very day the incident had occurred. There wasn't much to her save for the noticeable fear in her eyes and the bruises discreetly hidden under her clothes. 
  
 

  As he extended a sympathetic greeting to Annie, he observed her clutching her mobile phone tightly. She always carried her phone with her, a silent reminder of the threatening messages she received. It wasn't in the moment, but quite often did she seem to retreat into it for respite, even mid-conversation. "The modern security blanket," he mused.
  
 

  "Annie, we need to discuss your last interaction with Charlotte," he began softly. As he brought up Charlotte's name, he saw Annie flinch discernibly. There were scars of fear that were still fresh, some of them physical, it seemed, a weathered map of Charlotte's atrocities towards Annie etched into her psyche and on her body.
  
 

  Peering up briefly from the ground she had diverted her attention to, she confirmed in a whisper, "Yes detective, I was the last person to see her alive."
  
 

  Winston, carefully noting Annie's often downward gaze when discussing anything personal, led her gently into her house, promising to keep any discussion of abuse and threats brief. Even still, she could hardly keep focused. Any query about her encounters with Charlotte was met with a quick detour to safer topics. Winston sympathized; it was rare to come across a victim of abuse unwillfully enmeshed in the circumstances of their abuser.
  
 

  Her phone buzzed with a new message, and she busily unlocked it, her eyes flickering eagerly for the change in attention. Friends, as Winston noted, often shared her focus with the frequent check of her phone.
  
 

  A neighbor came by, offering her some comfort as well. Winston observed them interact - the perfect chance to bring up the witnessed incidents of abuse. From overheard insults to the occasional audible thud coming from the house when Charlotte would physically lash out, the neighbor painted a grim picture of Annie's life with Charlotte.
  
 

  Winston recognized the signs instantly, the clear dread of confrontation, the unwillingness to discuss personal matters. "It's obvious- she's trapped in an abusive relationship," he thought to himself. Annie's reticence made sense - her life was challenging enough without raking over painful memories.
  
 

  But it was clear more than ever - Annie was cornered. Stranded in a world where she was the victim of Charlotte’s aggression. Her dependence on her mobile phone and career as Charlotte's sole driver showed a desperate attempt to anchor herself to something stable.
  
 

  Sipping his lukewarm coffee, Winston listened more than he talked, realizing just how deep the story ran. In the heart of it was just a simple driver- trapped, abused, and scared. As he left, he hoped in earnest that the case would close soon. There was too much pain left unsaid.
  
 

  A weary Detective Winston sat in the backseat of the unmarked patrol car, watching the home where Letti was currently residing. He still had questions about the murder of Charlotte, questions that were gnawing at him. 
  
 

  He remembered speaking with Charlotte's housekeeper who confirmed that earlier that day, Charlotte had invited Letti over for dinner. Witnesses reported seeing Letti enter the victim's house. The housekeeper swore the two of them were alone in the kitchen. It was a space secluded from the rest of the house. Winston chocked it up to Charlotte's need for privacy. 
  
 

  Ironically, privacy was something that was now being invaded by the media. They'd been hounding Charlotte, trying to pry the truth out of her. The truth that Letti had possibly wanted to keep in the dark. 
  
 

  "Charlotte told Letti, 'I know what you did'," the housekeeper revealed during the interview. Winston wondered whether Charlotte knew something about Letti, something dangerous... something worth killing for. 
  
 

  Letti's reaction to Charlotte's statement, according to the housekeeper, had been intense. "The outburst... it was as if Letti was cornered or threatened," the housekeeper claimed.
  
 

  As he went over his notes, Winston's thoughts wandered to the security footage he had seen earlier. It was from a pawn shop, a shady establishment known to sell stun guns. The grainy footage dated back to earlier that day showed a woman matching Letti's description. The Pawn Shop's owner confirmed that she'd bought a stun gun.
  
 

  Letti had been taking self-defense classes. After seeing footage from her at a concert, Winston knew Letti could use a stun gun effectively. She wasn't just a groupie; she was more than what she appeared to be, a fact that was becoming painfully clear. 
  
 

  After a few more minutes, Winston made his decision. He needed to talk to Letti. He got out of the car, straightened his jacket, and walked towards the house, every fact etched deep into his mind.

  Detective Winston sat at a small, cluttered desk, scanning over the police reports and witness statements regarding the murder scene. His eyes narrowed in on a peculiar piece of information; Charlotte, the victim, had reportedly been stuffed. 
  
 

  "That's culinary," Winston muttered.
  
 

  The morning began with a visit to the local pet store, where Alan, a groupie with a penchant for exotic decor, was often spotted buying various animals. 
  
 

  "You've seen this woman before?" he asked, flashing his badge and a photograph of Alan towards the shopkeeper. 
  
 

  "Oh, yeah! She comes by often," the shopkeeper said cheerfully. "Always looking for some new pet to tag along with her to those concerts, I guess."
  
 

  "And what happens to these pets?"
  
 

  The shopkeeper's face contorted, his smile fading slightly. "Well... They just disappear, don't they? It's odd."
  
 

  His next stop was the scene of the murder: a secluded kitchen in Charlotte's home. According to her housekeeper, it was such place which Charlotte and Alan had been seen alone, sharing the early dinner Charlotte had invited her over for.
  
 

  Suddenly, a lead brought him to a Pawn Shop known for its wide array of self-defense equipment, stun guns in particular. Winston slid the security footage into the player, Alan appearing on the screen, her face a match to the shopkeeper's description.
  
 

  She was seen making a purchase, a stun gun catching his trained eye. Making an additional discovery, Winston found a newspaper article, along with some concert footage showing Alan using a stun gun effectively for self-defense during a music event. This was all coming together.
  
 

  Next, he turned towards a report stating Alan had recently signed up for self-defense classes - the kind that teaches stun gun usage. 
  
 

  His trail returning him to the pet store, Winston had found out that Alan had been at Charlotte's earlier in the day, according to a tip from a disgruntled neighbor.
  
 

  Upon hearing about the style in which the stuffing was done, detective Winston noted, Alan seemed to recognize it immediately. Could have been a coincidence, could have not; only time would tell.
  
  Doctor Winston had his work cut out for him, a tangle of clues, and facts left behind, waiting to be pieced together. He could see, however, that the threads of this mystery were starting to knit together. The mystery deepened the more he dug into it, each fact, each clue pulling him further into the complex web spun around the suspect. The only thing left to do was to pull the right string and observe as everything fell into place. With every step, the truth was seemingly closer, yet shrouded with enough obscurity to keep him on his toes.
  
 

  Winston was met with a distressed and nervous-looking woman when he arrived at Charlotte's house. Deborah was shaking, a pitiful sight, as she repeated her claim: "I was scared, I was really scared of her." She was a mess, with trembling hands and a trembling voice, but Winston had seen the proof of her fear in the way Charlotte treated her. Harsh treatment by a woman, once her employer and now her victim.
  
 

  Apparently, Deborah had been scheduled to drive Charlotte that very day; a service she always offered. In all honesty, it seemed Deborah was Charlotte's only method of transportation. Winston couldn't help but wonder, though, at the intensity of her fear. Was it because of Charlotte's abusive behavior, evidenced by bruises and the testimonies of her neighbors? Or was it due to ominous messages that Charlotte had sent Deborah?
  
 

  Deborah's fear seemed to have had a history of manifesting physically. The word was out that she had employed a stun gun in the past, for self-protection as Winston understood. Deborah was never far from it, the weapon always at her side.
  
 

  Just then, Winston noticed a license on her wall. "Used to be a personal security guard, I see," he commented, pointing towards it. Deborah just nodded in agreement, a simple affirmative to Winston's observation. Strange how life can take unexpected turns, Winston thought.
  
 

  "Deborah," Winston started, his tone soothing, "can you tell me what exactly happened when Charlotte... died?" Deborah hesitated, her eyes moving towards the stun gun on the table. An eerily similar device was collected from the crime scene.
  
 

  "Well, I..." she stammered, "I, um, was the last person to see her. I... I found her... in the kitchen." Her voice was barely audible, a whisper barely able to carry the weight of her confession. 
  
 

  Winston didn't say anything. He simply nodded before standing up, thanking Deborah for her time and promising to be in contact. He left the house, lost in his thoughts. There was much to ponder over in this investigation. After all, the puzzle of the case was only just beginning to reveal itself.

context:
In a chilling turn of events, Rose is found lifeless in a car, killed by a vial of acid, leading Detective Winston to the affluent suspects, Grace, who is Asian, and Dexter.
  
 

  Winston was going over the facts of the case when he decided to visit the suspect, Grace. Grace wasn't your typical suspect - she was a singer who always had a passion for her art form, a passion that stood in sharp contrast with her family's dismissive attitude.
  
 

  “I'm just trying to get ahead in life, you know?" she told Winston as they sat in a small cafe near one of her repeat performance venues - an old building that was frequently harshly criticised for its lack of cleanliness. "They never cared about my music… always thought it was just a phase. I couldn't stand their lack of support.”
  
 

  Getting rid of her family members from her contacts was, as she put it, a "cleansing experience". It was all very telling of Grace's meticulous nature - she extended the same cleanliness philosophy to everything in her personal life, hygiene being her top priority; it gave a stark contrast to the venues in which she performed.
  
 

  After a moment of silence, she casually added, "Sometimes my sarcasm gets the best of me. I can't tell you how many family dinners I've ruined with it. My sarcasm stings so hard, it often leaves them in tears."
  
 

  Winston thought about Rose, who often parked her car in the same vicinity. "You were scheduled to perform at a place near that parking lot that day… right?" he asked. Grace affirmed the fact and mentioned having seen Rose's car, acknowledging that she and Rose were the last two people in the vehicle after her show that night.
  
 

  As part of her performances, Grace often integrated different kinds of acid into her routines - the same kind, as it turned out, that had been used to murder Rose. A cold chill ran down Winston’s spine as he mentally cross-checked the evidence list.
  
 

  “Acid isn’t a typical instrument for a singer, Grace..." Winston quizzed, trying to keep the conversation casual. Grace just shrugged, "Got to create a spectacle, right? Attract an audience?”
  
 

  Grace had always been adamant about not attending any family gatherings - a fact that did not change even after Rose’s death. But she claimed to hold no ill-will towards Rose. As Winston got up from the table to leave, he turned one final time to look at Grace who was now alone and engrossed in her phone. A suspect or not, one thing was certain, the story was far from over.
  
 

  As Winston sat in his office, he sifted through the photos of the crime scene. The car where Rose had met her gruesome end was familiar to him - it was the one Dexter had sold her just a few days ago. He recalled the witness statement he had received, stating that Dexter and Rose were seen driving off in the new car together on the day of the sale.
  
 

  A few days prior, he had stopped by the car dealership for a chat with Dexter. The man was always excitable, energetic - the sort of person you'd expect to be selling cars. But beneath that facade, Winston had glimpsed an undertone of tension. A hint of worry, perhaps? He remembered too the bold campaign posters dotting the walls of the showroom - 'Dexter for Office' they proclaimed, his smiling face lit up by the flash of a professional camera. Maintaining a decent public image was crucial for his campaign.
  
 

  "Beautiful machine, ain't she?" Dexter had commented, patting the bonnet of the vehicle with an almost reverential air. His eyes had been bright as he spoke, "Takes skill to appreciate such precision and quality."
  
 

  A brief moment of silence had hung over them before Winston mentioned Rose. Instantly, the twitch in Dexter's smile was noticeable as he forced a chuckle, "She got a good deal on this one. I even had a ride in it with her, that's what earned her trust."
  
 

  As a detective, one didn't always have the luxury of trusting words at face value. Dexter seemed too polished - too adept at projecting an image. Most importantly, Winston had known about his run for the local office. A scandal was not what he needed. Rose had found out about Dexter's false credentials, and threatened him with exposure.
  
 

  Winston also remembered the demure set of eyes that stared back at him from an old campus photo during a visit to Dexter's home. Dexter had a degree in Chemistry. Neat rows of labeled chemicals stood proudly on a shelf in his private garage. The detective recognized some of them from his own time in the forensics lab. He had seen the vials labeled 'Acid'. Winston had asked Dexter about the key trace elements for his car sales. Dexter had just brushed it off with a laugh, mentioning they were required for cleaning and various other mundane tasks around the sales lot.
  
 

  Back at his office, the image of the second set of car keys on Dexter's table resurfaced in his mind. Dexter had explained them as a precaution, an insurance if customers ever lost their keys.
  
 

  "Coffee?" Winston's assistant knocked on his office door, pulling him out of his thoughts.
  
 

  "No thanks," the detective replied, scribbling something down in his notebook before shuffling his case files together. "I think I need some fresh air. Let's do a round at the car dealership."

In a chilling turn of events, Rose is found lifeless in a car, killed by a vial of acid, leading Detective Winston to the affluent suspects, Daisy and Winnie, an individual of Asian descent,.
  
 

  Detective Winston found himself in the showroom of a car dealership. He was eyeing one of the employees behind the counter, a man named Winnie. The guy was tall, slender, and had a bright grin, almost always painted across his face. Winnie was seen engrossing himself with trinkets that sat on the edge of his desk. These weren't just ordinary trinkets, many of them were uniquely car-related, including miniature replicas of cars engines and pieces that Winnie had personally worked on with his chemical expertise. He smiled lightly as he fiddled with them.
  
 

  As Winston approached him, Winnie looked up, and his eyes momentarily flickered with recognition before he composed his features into a salesman’s grin. After introducing himself, Winston mentioned Rose and watched for any reactions. But Winnie's face remained impassive, his salesman smile never wavering.
  
 

  Instead of just being a mere salesman, Winnie was also the chief mechanic of the dealership, utilizing his extensive background in chemistry to invent more advanced car maintenance techniques using various chemicals. His clear talent in this area provided him with a unique edge over other car sale businesses. As his shift ended, Winnie led Winston to his home, speaking eagerly about his run for a local office. 
  
 

  As they entered Winnie’s living room, Winston noticed a big box sitting against one wall. Piled around it were numerous trinkets, ranging from keychains to pens, from figurines to pocket watches. When Winston enquired about the assortment, Winnie revealed his routine of adding to the box each time he made a new customer. To demonstrate, he showed Winston a trinket he had recently added, telling the detective about the customer he met that day. It was his way of commemorating their interactions.
  
 

  The home was filled with telling signs of his life. One thing that caught Winston's eye was a photo album lying open on the coffee table. It exhibited Winnie with various people, captions scribbled underneath each picture capturing pleasurable memories.
  
 

  Their conversation eventually shifted to Winnie’s basement, and his workspace was introduced. Odd for a car salesman but not for an in-house mechanic, his workspace was filled with extensive glassware and chemicals, including several bottles of acid which Winnie often used in his inventive car mechanic works. He confirmed to Winston about his background in chemistry before becoming a mechanic and eventually a car salesman.
  
 

  Just as Winston was preparing to leave, Winnie mentioned something that instantly shocked him. Rose had threatened to expose him. She had figured out that he had been dishonest about his qualifications. Hiding his surprise, Winston empathically responded, and Winnie merely smiled, affirming how damaging Rose's threats were to his public image and his ongoing electoral campaign.
  
 

  With the resonating echo of Winnie’s last words, Winston bid his goodbyes, exiting with suspicious thoughts playing heavily on his mind. Not only was Winnie's public image important for his election hopes but, as a renowned mechanic, any scandal could also potentially tarnish his reputation within the car dealership.
  
 

  The detective, Winston, had strong coffee in his hand as he reviewed the case files laid out in front of him. His current assignment was the murder of Rose, who was found dead in her car by means of an acid attack. The type of acid was identical to those found in Daisy's performances. The perpetrator got away, leaving only a vial as evidence.
  
 

  Rose had frequent parking spots, and her car was often seen in the lot near the locals' favorite music venue. The night she was killed, she was leaving a concert that was being performed by Daisy, a singer scheduled to perform at the same venue near the parking lot that day. Rose also notably had a sizable life insurance policy, to which Daisy was added as a beneficiary just a month before the incident.
  
 

  Daisy was known for her meticulously neat dressing room. She claimed it came from her aversion to the generally dirty environment the venues offered. Daisy's music album sales had been falling drastically, attested by the revenue charts Winston was scrutinizing. Furthermore, due to the cancellation of many events due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Daisy had been unable to collect performance fees.
  
 

  During the middle of the practice session, Winston visited Daisy, where she was preparing for her next performance. He noticed different types of acids in small containers labeled and neatly arranged on a side table. Upon inquiry, Daisy shared how she often incorporated the acids into her performances for dramatic effects. She jokingly added, "You should see the mess they make sometimes; this place is never clean."
  
 

  Witnesses from the concert reported seeing Daisy and Rose leaving the venue together after the show. They appeared to be the only ones in the car. Daisy didn't hesitate to confirm, "Oh, yes, Rose and I left the venue together. She was kind enough to offer me a lift, as my own ride bailed out."
  
 

  As Winston left the venue, his phone buzzed, reminding him of Daisy's recent addition to Rose's sizable life insurance policy just a month ago. As he drove past the venue, he saw that it was right next to the parking lot where Rose frequented. With the vial of similar acid on his mind, the pieces were starting to fall into place for Winston.
  
 

  Despite making some strides, the detective knew that the journey to justice was far from over. Each new location and piece of information held the potential to be the key to unraveling the mystery behind Rose's death.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

context:
In the bustling labyrinth of a city mall, a grisly murder sends shockwaves as Xenia is killed with a nail gun, leaving Detective Winston with two perplexing suspects: Van and Queenie, a person of Asian heritage,.
  
 

  Detective Winston felt his chest tighten slightly as he stepped onto the crime scene. Another murder, and this time - a shopping mall. Xenia, the victim, a blond woman in her early forties. Falling under the jurisdiction of his detective expertise, Winston gathered the scattered bits of facts and evidence that were available up to this point.
  
 

  The murder weapon, a nail gun, an unusual choice. That fact alone put Winston’s investigation into a small percentage of the population who had access to such tools - contractors. And with this unfortunate coincidence was the fact that the nail gun used in the crime was reported missing from Queenie's construction project, which made for even a more compelling lead to pursue. 
  
 

  Court sessions were known to be highly stressful, creating a complete sense of tension in the courtroom, causing lawyers like Queenie to sweat profusely. Yet, even under such stressful circumstances Queenie always maintained a fresh scent.
  
 

  Upon hearing this, his mind immediately turned to Queenie, a local lawyer who was a known aficionado of construction, something that would give him easy access to nail guns. 
  
 

  Winston sent out a request for surveillance footage of Queenie's construction site, hoping to gain some insight into whether Queenie had any interaction with nail guns. 
  
 

  He also requested the mall’s CCTV footage, given that Xenia was killed in the mall. The footage verified Queenie’s presence in the mall around the same time Xenia was murdered. But that wasn't the evidence that caught Winston’s eye. It was the traces of bakery flour, always noticeable on Queenie's shoes. 
  
 

  Queenie was known to spend significant amounts of time on his feet in the courtroom, often sweating profusely due to the stressful court sessions. Yet a remarkable trait about Queenie was that he maintained a fresh scent, even after a long day. This always intrigued Winston; however, upon further investigation, he discovered Queenie's secret was the luxury of having a bathroom with a shower in his office; thus the puzzle started to come together.
  
 

  The authorities were unsure of Queenie's exact location during the murder. Nobody could verify his whereabouts and the time Xenia was killed, Queenie was unaccounted for, posing a substantial mystery for Winston to solve.
  
 

  As he continued his investigation, Winston implemented a strategic approach to obtain more information. He planned a meeting with Queenie under the pretext of discussing a case, and at the scheduled meeting, he carefully observed the unassuming lawyer.
  
 

  "When's the last time you visited your construction project, Queenie?" Winston asked, keeping a close eye on the man's reactions.
  
 

  "Monday, as I recall," Queenie responded, not missing a beat. "Why do you ask?"
  
 

  "Just curiosity. You ever handle a nail gun before?"
  
 

  Queenie offered a nonchalant shrug. "Sure. Comes with the territory."
  
 

  Winston noted the answer, pressing further. "And how about the mall? Been there recently?”
  
 

  Queenie nodded, stating, "Oh, yes, a couple of times this week."
  
 

  In the end, Winston came out of the meeting with more questions than answers, but the strings of information were beginning to shape a premise. One thing was certain - Queenie was irrefutably intertwined in this case.
  
 

  Winston swept through the shopping mall like water, eyes scanning, earpiece transmitting information straight to the station. He was looking for Van, who had been on shift when Xenia was killed.
  
 

  He spotted a muscular man with a nametag was unloading boxes from a service entrance, huffing and puffing as he went. "Looks like our guy," he mumbled into his headset.
  
 

  "I've been expecting you," said Van, the bodybuilder, wiping his sweat-drenched forehead with a well-charred sleeve. He pointed to a chair across the table, "Have a seat, will you?"
  
 

  Winston did, and before he even opened his mouth, Van was speaking, "You know, Xenia was here almost every day. She loved this place, loved shopping. Sad thing what happened."
  
 

  Winston, not one for small talk, started grilling Van, "You were on shift when she was killed, right Van?"
  
 

  "Yeah, I was," he replied. "I ain't seen nothing though."
  
 

  "What does your job entail?" Winston asked, changing the subject.
  
 

  "I've got free run of this place. Lock, stock and barrel, I can move about as I please,” Van said, directing an intense look at Winston's face.  
  
 

  "Your hobbies, Van?" 
  
 

  "Used to build furniture for a living," He admitted, "It was a bit of an obsession for a while. Even took a safety course from the local construction company."
  
 

  "Did you now," Winston nodded, “Do you happen to own a nail gun?”
  
 

  “Bought one recently, yes,” Van said, as casually as if he were talking about the weather. “Receipt’s right here in my wallet.”
  
 

  "Thanks for sharing. Are you aware that Xenia recently updated her will, making you the sole beneficiary?” The detective shifted the conversation back onto Xenia.
  
 

  “It’s funny you say that, because I did have her change her life insurance policy at the same time,” Van shared, ”I hadn’t thought of it… till now…” He paused, looking contemplative for a moment. 
  
 

  Winston got a call that disturbed him, "Excuse me, I must go.”
  
 

  He remembered the mail they found at Van’s house: confirmation from the hardware store of buying a nail gun the same model as the murder weapon. It added up.
  
 

  Before leaving, Winston couldn't help but casually ask, "The insurance payout from her will, that a large sum?"
  
 

  "God-awful massive," Van answered after a moment of hesitation, "And here I am buried under... well, a heap of bills, I'd rather not disclose."
  
 

  With that, the detective left, collecting the pieces as he went.

context:
When Wendy's life brutally ended under the sharp end of a pickaxe at the local roller rink, it was up to the shrewd Detective Winston to untangle the web spun around two prime suspects, Marianne and Vicky, an Asian individual,.
  
 

  Detective Winston tapped his pen against the mugshot of Marianne. She wore the hardened expression of a seasoned miner, and a sprinkle of white dust beaded her forehead. She had, years ago, spent a considerable amount of time underground before she traded the pickaxe for a ring. Even after her marriage, however, Winston knew that Marianne was not unfamiliar with the heft and purpose of such a tool.
  
 

  His eyes consisted of the audit papers laid out before him, declaring a significant debt that Marianne owed in back taxes. She was circling financial demise, and the state was closing in. Then, his eyes shifted to the statement provided by a friend of hers, highlighting her strong assertion that she would rather perish than get sent behind bars. It seemed to Winston that Marianne was still filled with the spirits of the old miners, willing to risk it all in pursuit of her own freedom.
  
 

  His venture out to her parcel of land a few days back had stamped the image in his mind of her mining tools lounging out in the open. They were well-kept and clean, the way old miners kept their tools. Marianne had been spotted around the community with the pickaxe, using it for various garden works and general maintenance.
  
 

  Now Winston's attention moved to Wendy, the victim, an honest lady known for her earnest ways. She was found in a sequestered section of the roller rink, a roller skate still hanging onto her foot as if she was frozen mid-skate.
  
 

  Placing a call, Winston requested the CCTV footage of the roller rink from the night of the murder. There, in the flickering low resolution, was Wendy locked in a heated argument with Marianne. The dispute ended and Wendy skated off, but Marianne stayed.
  
 

  Later, another clip showed Marianne lingering along the outskirts, long after the other skaters had left. It was an eerie sight - the roller rink was empty, except for the flickering neon lights and Marianne, circling the rink with an unsettling calmness.
  
 

  Winston slid an envelope towards himself and carefully extracted a photograph. It was Wendy's last piece of brave detective work - a picture of Marianne caught in a grim action that served as undeniable proof of her crime. But it was Wendy, with her unwavering integrity, who held this tight to her chest, vowing to expose the truth about Marianne.
  
 

  Two cups of coffee empty, Winston switched off the lights and left the room. The image of Marianne and the pickaxe lingered in the darkness of the office, the unsaid words and whispers of the CCTV footage bouncing off the walls. The unwelcome truth seemed to have found a perfect partner with the impending dawn, unflinching and relentless.
  
 

  Pencil in hand, a room full of boxes filled with countless pads of stationary and envelopes, Winston scrolled through the dossier one more time. Vicky, the geologist who loved to write letters and the company of a well-worn roller rink.
  
 

  Winston headed to the local rink to further his investigation. The sticky, stale scent of overused roller skates greeting him as he walked in. The roller rink was bustling with murmurs about the murder that had taken place there the previous night during Vicky's usual hours at the rink, further thickening the air with tension.
  
 

  The staff recognized him the second he walked through the door. "Detective Winston," they greeted. "Come about the Vicky matter?" 
  
 

  Winston nodded, face impassive, “He’s a regular around here, isn’t he? And he was here last night too?"
  
 

  “Heck, we'd see him here every other night, including last night,” one replied. "Always came in right around the same time.” Winston noted the staff’s response verbatim.
  
 

  “And this uh…Wendy? Seen her around with Vicky?” 
  
 

  Pausing, a staff member nodded. "Yes, they've been seen together few times at the rink. Wendy told us she knew a secret about Vicky, something that could humiliate him if it got out and that she already shared this secret with her friends. In fact, the secret she told was indeed damaging; it was about Vicky's misconduct in his reputable profession that if revealed, would certainly ruin him publicly."
  
 

  The information tucked away in his mind, Winston thanked the rink staff. He turned his mind to Jack, Vicky’s imprisoned friend with notorious criminal record.
  
 

  He walked out to his car, rummaging for his mobile, tapped a number. "Yes, I need to speak with Jack. Yes, the one in cell 108."
  
 

  The next stop was the post office, where stacks upon stacks of letters, each written by Vicky using his large collection of stationary and postage stamps could be seen. "Yeah, he's in here often,” the postmistress shared without hesitation. 
  
 

  Winston mulled over this, pocketed his notepad, and headed to Vicky's home with a stern knock on the door.
  
 

  Vicky let him in, launching into endless stories involving Jack as if it were an unconcerned topic. But when Wendy's name dropped, his jovial manner evaporated and his demeanor drastically changed. "That's a lie!" Vicky protested vehemently when Winston cautiously picked up the subject Wendy had told her friends involving a ruinous secret that's been said she knew about Vicky. "She had no idea what she was talking about. All her talk was to intentionally defame me in public." The denial was fervent, almost desperate.
  
 

  Winston offered no consolation. It wasn’t his job. He stepped away from Vicky’s house, a new puzzle piece in hand. His work, the unraveling of the truth, was far from done.

  Pieces started falling into place; too many strings tethered Annie to the night Wendy was murdered. With a sigh, Winston allowed himself a quiet moment. Then, taking a deep breath, he began his descent into the intricacies of the case before him.
  
 

  Winston stood at the entrance of the roller rink, eyes scanning the room. The images from the crime scene report replayed in his memory. Poor Wendy had breathed her last in what was supposed to be a place filled with the rejuvenating sounds of retro music and flashing lights.
  
 

  Sidney, who was a geologist, had been seen with Wendy at the roller rink multiple times. According to the staff, Sidney was even a regular here. He frequently carried his tools, including his pickaxe, from his daytime geological survey sites directly to the roller rink in the evenings.
  
 

  Checking his notes from the previous conversation with Sidney, his eyebrows knitted slightly as he remembered the desperation he sensed from Sidney. It revolved around Wendy, who apparently knew something he coveted as a secret. She had been sharing this secret with her friends and it seemed it held the power to publicly humiliate Sidney if it ever came to light. Sidney, for his part, vehemently denied any secret of such scale.
  
 

  Winston gestured for the barista to come over. The young man with a skater haircut glanced at Winston's badge before he ordered a black coffee with no sugar. While waiting for his order, he asked, “Did you notice Sidney here during the time of the incident?”
  
 

  The barista nodded, nervously biting his lower lip. "Yes, Detective. Sidney was here. I remember seeing him."
  
 

  Winston nodded as he continued his observations. His gaze lingered over Sidney's station where he parked his geologist’s gear, including his trusted pickaxe, which he used during his geological field trips, when he visited. He noticed the stains of usual wear and tear and a freshly cleaned pickaxe leaning against the wall. Nothing unusual for a geologist. Taking down notes, Winston silently queued the information; the same Pickaxe might have been used for the murder.
  
 

  His phone buzzed breaking his trail of thoughts, He took the informer's call. He glanced at his watch noting down the time of the conversation before disconnecting the call. He finished his coffee and left the roller rink. He had to confirm if Wendy was indeed telling the truth about that secret or Sidney was just an innocent geologist who loved rollerblading and hated gossips.

  "She did confront me, yes. Said something about me having been involved in past crimes. I did not...," her voice quivered, trailing off.
  
 

  "You were seen arriving at Tessa's place that evening. But, oddly enough, nobody actually saw you leave...why do you suppose that is?" Winston asked, deliberately amplifying the tension.

  "But still, no sightings of your departure?" Winston pressed.

Winston asked, pausing to lean back on his chair, "To my understanding, all other businesses in the area were highly cooperative. Was Tessa the only one resisting the expansion?"
  
 

  "Yes, sir." Name said, her tone defensive. "And every time I tried to talk to Tessa about it, maybe cut a deal, she wasn't having it. She was the only stubborn holdout against my proposals."
  
 

  "I see." Winston scribbled a note on the paper in front of him, shielding it from view with a well-practiced arm block. "Dealing with hazardous materials... that's part of police training, right? You've taken classes for that?"

  "Have any hobbies, Officer Name?"

  "Well...yes," Name admitted, nearly blushing. "We frequently meet up at my place to discuss the latest thriller."
  
 

  Downing the last dregs of his cold coffee, Winston pushed away from the table and stood to leave. "Well, Officer Name," he said, pulling on his weathered leather jacket. "It seems there is much I need to ponder. We'll take it from here. Thank you for your time."

Mia, the waitress at the bowling alley, knew about Joel's regular late-night bowling habits. Perhaps due to this, Joel often ended up bowling late on the nights Mia was working.
  
 

  She then recalled one unnerving evening—Joel explicitly threatening to unveil a potent political scandal that would surely taint her reputation if ever it reached the public. Shivers ran down her spine with the cold memory.
  
 

  As Winston walked away, he took one last glance back at Mia. Her eyes looked like they were both emancipating and imprisoning secrets she would rather stay hidden. Winston knew his work was far from over.
  
 

  Winston scanned the crime scene photos of the late-night bowling alley murder for the umpteenth time, swiveling lazily in his office chair. Joel, the victim, had unfortunately found his end using a pair of nunchaku, a brutal, yet strangely eccentric way for a life to be taken - and that too after official business hours, an unusual occasion at the alley.
  
 

  He downed the last of his coffee and grabbed his jacket, ready to conduct another careful suspect interview. He set out to find Grace, who had been working her overtime shift at the bowling alley when the murder occurred eerily during the late after hours.
  
 

  Stepping into the buzzing local bar, candlelight bounced off the myriad of glass bottles lining the walls, all reachable only by ladders that the bartenders navigated with incredible balance. Grace, carting herself from the fridge to the counter, looked up at Winston as he approached. She looked perfectly graceful, a stark contrast to her claim of frequently bumping into things.
  
 

  "Grace, I presume," Winston opened, his gaze lingering on her form, conspicuously clad in a long-sleeved shirt despite the warm ambient temperature.
  
 

  "That's correct," she responded, her voice warm yet curt. As she reached for a bottle on a high shelf, she winced slightly. "Got a stiff shoulder. Those martial arts gym workouts can be taxing sometimes," she casually mentioned, subtly revealing her regular gym sessions.
  
 

  "I'm aware of your regular participation in nunchaku workshops at the local martial arts gym," Winston commented, given her previous statement. Grace chuckled, responding with a flex of her arms, clearly hinting at her muscular strength. Her attention moved toward a set of keys she was fiddle around with.
  
 

  "Bowling alley keys. Part of the job," she explained before he had to ask, and then another conversation to make small talk deftly guided by the detective.
  
 

  "Some nice nunchaku you have up there," Winston finally stated, nodding toward a martial-arts weapons display above the bar.
  
 

  "Inherited," she said with a slight nod. "Practiced a bit. It's art you know."
  
 

  Before Winston could subtly inquire about her bowling alley shift on the night of the murder, another customer called her away. Yet, his observations continued as she navigated through the bar serving drinks - she moved flawlessly, despite her prior claim of clumsiness.
  
 

  Leaving the bar, Winston mulled over the information he gathered - Grace had worked at the bowling alley on the fateful night, she had keys to the place as part of her job, had trained in using and collected nunchaku, was a regular at the martial arts gym, and had inherited a collection of martial-arts weapons. All these shaped another puzzle for him to solve.
  
 

  Winston was no stranger to dealing with loose ends and carefully sifting fact from fiction. But even with the facts he gathered from Grace's interview, Joel's perpetrator was still elusive. The only certainty was the haunting image of the murder weapon, nunchaku, which were a significant part of Grace's life. The case was far from closed.

In the mystifying quiet of a mosque, Isabella was found lifeless, a nunchaku the lone cause, casting Detective Winston into a whirlwind investigation with suspects Malaysia and Dan, who is Asian, at the heart of the mystery.
  
 

  Detective Winston regarded the lone figure sitting before him across the table. Dan’s face was absorbed in the glow of the paused true crime documentary, his eyes reflecting morbid fascination and intense concentration. 
  
 

  "Dan?" Winston called out, cutting through the gloomy silence, drawing the man's attention away from the screen. The detective's brows furrowed curiously at the patterned sweat marks on Dan's shirt, as well as abrasions on his hand.
  
 

  "Just finishing up your work-out?" Winston asked, gesturing towards the sweat-soaked shirt.
  
 

  "Ah, yes, detective," Dan confessed, catching on to his implication. "Those marks? I was practicing my nunchaku techniques in the martial arts class before you arrived. Quite challenging to get the swings right. Purchased these nunchaku from a sports equipment store last month. It's part of my martial arts training."
  
 

  "Martial arts? I wouldn’t have expected that from a waiter," Winston said, conversing readily.
  
 

  "The mosque I work at, it's next to this martial arts institution. We do nunchaku training as part of our drills. Isabella, tragically enough, was also a part of the same class, and I just like keeping myself engaged." Dan shrugged.
  
 

  "Speaking of keeping engaged," Winston glanced towards the paused documentary on the laptop, "Looks like you've got quite the fascination with true crime, huh?"
  
 

  "I listen, rewind, analyze, and repeat..." Dan said, reaching towards his notebook that lay next to the computer, brimming with his own investigation strategies, "I write down interesting details. I find it... intriguing, to say the least."
  
 

  "Ah, a keen observer. Useful in a job like yours," Winston said, nodding in understanding. 
  
 

  "I rarely interact with anyone outside my working hours, detective," Dan asserted with a hint of defensiveness, immediately finishing off his sentence. "The day the tragedy happened, I was at the martial arts class first, then I went to the mosque...but I was alone."
  
 

  The glint in Dan's eyes gave away nothing, but Winston saw the flicker of insight deepen. With a curt nod, he stood up, leaving Dan in the expanse of his own silence. As the day drew to a close, Winston had to acknowledge one thing - Dan was an enigma, much like the case he found himself entangled in.
  
 

  Detective Winston was having one hell of a day, nursing a mug of coffee that had long since turned cold with the reports strewn about on his desk. 
  
 

  A crime was reported, suspicious activity by a local hairdresser named Malaysia, notorious for her volatile behavior. Some customers claimed to see her practicing martial arts in the salon in her free time. Malaysia was also often seen at home practicing her martial arts moves and had even purchased a pair of nunchaku. She had a fondness for martial arts revered from her high school days when she attended martial arts classes. She was a fervent admirer of martial arts movies, and supposedly sought to bring some of those electrifying martial arts stunts to life.
  
 

  On the day of the crime, Malaysia was not on her workplace's schedule. This was a detail that leaped out of her shoddy alibi. Noting her erratic behavior, a lady named Isabella had found it suspicious. She even reported her concerns to the authorities.
  
 

  With this lead in hand, Winston headed towards Malaysia’s place. A variety of martial arts equipment arranged delicately welcomed him, including the purchased pair of nunchaku, the kind usually bought by hardcore martial arts supporters and fighters. 
  
 

  A gentle voice pulled him back from his thoughts when Malaysia invited him inside. It turned out that martial arts was more than just a hobby for her; it was embedded in every crevice of her life. Interestingly, she mentioned visiting a nearby mosque, which she had loved since childhood. She had always frequented the mosque, participating in various volunteering activities and contributing to its well-being.
  
 

  In the middle of their conversation, a couple of police officers joining them, interrogating Malaysia about a theft. The stolen items were eventually found in her possession, which made Winston arch an eyebrow, but he said nothing.
  
 

  The same mosque was the place where Isabella, the one who had noticed and reported Malaysia’s suspicious behavior, was murdered. 
  
 

  Winston stood silently, observing Malaysia during the conversation, before excusing himself from her apartment and returning to his office. His coffee was still tepid and the files hadn’t moved, but somehow, he saw the case from a different perspective.

context:
In the mystifying quiet of a mosque, Isabella was found lifeless, a nunchaku the lone cause, casting Detective Winston into a whirlwind investigation with suspects Jerry, a person of Asian heritage, and Richard at the heart of the mystery.
  
 

  Detective Winston was in his office, pouring over the facts of the Isabella case. Isabella was a young woman murdered in a mosque with a pair of nunchaku. Her case was sent to him because not only was the method of murder unusual but the strange behavior she'd reported was disconcerting.
  
 

  Isabella had reported suspicious activity to the authorities, claiming an acquaintance named Jerry was acting out of sorts. The name Jerry was ringing alarm bells for Winston. The police had already questioned her regarding a theft, and now, with Isabella's murder, he felt the need to dig deeper.
  
 

  Winston knocked on the door of Jerry's small home, case files in hand. She was a hairdresser by trade, known to be a fan of martial arts movies, placing Bruce Lee as her idol, and had a knack for practicing martial arts moves at home. She had purchased nunchaku recently.  
  
 

  Winston was greeted with a jovial smile when he arrived, and once pleasantries were exchanged, his questions began.
  
 

  “I noticed a uniform in that bag by your door,” Winston nodded towards the corner of the room. “You do martial arts?”
  
 

  “Sure do,” she replied cheerfully. “Nothing like a little kick and a punch after a long day, especially after watching a good martial arts movie.”
  
 

  Winston watched her closely but Jerry seemed to only speak the truth. “Did you ever take martial arts classes?”
  
 

  Jerry chuckled, “Does high school count? I took it for a few years then. I was a Bruce Lee in the making.”
  
 

  He took a deep breath and continued, “What about your family, Jerry?” Winston asked, trying to dig into her background. 
  
 

  Jerry shrugged. “Well detective, it's as erratic as the weather these days. Speaking of which, I do believe we are in for some rain later today."
  
 

  Feeling slightly exasperated, Winston decided to prod a bit more. "And your love life, Jerry?" he asked. 
  
 

  "Oh, it's like 'Gone With The Wind'," she replied, winking at him. "An epic which suddenly disappears. Like any good movie, wouldn't you agree, Winston?"
  
 

  He decided to tread lightly. “You ever practice with nunchaku?”
  
 

  Jerry’s gaze never wavered, “Oh, sure. Bought a pair recently. They came in handy when Isabella tried taking my TV. Those are some nice detective notes you've got there around a theft, happened a few days ago, isn't it? The police already asked me about those."
  
 

  As Winston left Jerry's home, he was left with a feeling of uncertainty. There was much to unravel about this peculiar woman, and he still couldn’t shake off the uneasy feeling of her jovial exterior that hid a string of suspicious facts. Isabella might have been gone, but Winston was determined to uncover the truth for her sake.
  
 

  Winston eyed the austere environment of the mosque, draped in silence and shadows. As he looked at this deserted place of worship, he thought of the vibrant Isabella, now lying lifeless.
  
 

  Remembering his conversations with Isabella's friends, he couldn't help but recall them saying how determined she was to escape Richard for good. Isabella's friends had mentioned her to him - how she told them she intended to finally break free from Richard permanently.
  
 

  He decided to talk to Richard, a local waiter who had been working at the mosque during those deserted, deadly hours that took Isabella's life.
  
 

  Richard stood by the main entryway, enduring the barrage of lights and unfamiliar faces. Winston recognized him from his not-so-distant encounter with the law - a case of domestic violence involving him and Isabella.
  
 

  "Evening, Richard," Winston started, extending a friendly hand. "Been working here long?"
  
 

  "Few months, sir," Richard replied, his voice steady. "Only serve the occasional visitor during the day. I was alone yesterday. No one else was here."
  
 

  Winston nodded, making a mental note of Richard's presence at the mosque during the time of Isabella's murder. "I've seen you before. A martial arts class, wasn't it?"
  
 

  Richard's gaze flickered with surprise before he recovered, his professional mask back in place. "Yes. Same class as Isabella."
  
 

  Winston recalled seeing Richard in that martial arts class, practicing nunchaku - the same weapon that had ended Isabella's life. And not too long ago, he had seen him at the local sports equipment store, purchasing a set of nunchaku.
  
 

  "Quite a skill you've got there," Winston continued, keeping his voice casual. "Heard you and Isabella trained together."
  
 

  Richard sighed, his gaze flicked towards the mosque's silent dome. "Yeah, we both were there. Couldn't seem to get away from each other.”
  
 

  "I'm sure," Winston agreed. Neighbors had reported frequently hearing the couple arguing, their quarrels escalating in intensity. "How was Isabella doing?"
  
 

  Richard paused, his brow furrowed. "She... She was... planning to leave."
  
 

  "Leave?" Winston asked, knowing that Isabella had finally decided to break free from Richard permanently. She had even confided in her friends about her escape plans and purchased a ticket for a one-way trip out of the country.
  
 

  "Yes..." Richard's voice was barely audible. "Leave me. Leave everything."
  
 

  With that, Winston thanked Richard and turned to leave, his thoughts spinning around the tragic tale of Isabella, her life brutally ended in this quiet mosque she had formerly sought peace.

context:
In the sweltering heat of the desert, Detective Winston finds himself amid the ashes of the flamethrower murder of Renee, with Paige and David, an individual of Asian descent, emerging as the prime suspects.
  
 

  Winston opened the thick manila folder labeled 'Renee' on his desk and took in the basic information once again. As he smoothed the slightly wrinkled photograph of the victim, he couldn't help but acknowledge the gravity of the murder that had taken place out in the desolate stretches of the desert.
  
 

  "Heard you requested a flamethrower for your workshop," Winston started as he visited Paige, Renee's mentee, at her special effects shop. She let him in, even showing him around her tools which included a newly acquired flamethrower for realistic movie effects, which she was seen handling just a few days ago. Winston remembered walking by the open garage door and catching a glimpse of Paige playing with the flamethrower, her face what he could only describe as an excited child with a new toy.
  
 

  "May I ask if you were the last person seen with Renee?" Winston asked.
  
 

  "Yes, detective, I was," Paige answered. 
  
 

  Seeing no reason to evade the question, Paige mentioned how she repeatedly advised Renee to retire from her line of work. "She was always stubborn and distant, especially with me," Paige shared, an indication of Renee trying to distance herself. "She was in her sixties but she refused to slow down, causing me to feel constant frustration and would frequently make me lash out," Paige confided. "It always upset me," she further admitted her thoughts, letting Winston understand the volatile mentor-protege relationship dynamics.
  
 

  Winston nodded, storing this important information about the dynamics between Paige and Renee. "I have found out from the delivery company that a flamethrower was delivered to this workshop recently. Was it yours? The one you ordered?"
  
 

  "Yes, that's correct," Paige replied, her face unchanging. "You see, I work in special effects. I deal with all sorts of contraptions, including flamethrowers. They're not as deadly as they seem, you know? Only in the wrong hands..."
  
 

  It seemed like Paige was positioning herself just within the edge of suspicion, but Winston kept his thoughts to himself, a stoic expression fixed on his face. He then asked about Paige's closeness with the desert, a quick detour from her workshop. 
  
 

  "Oh, it's easily accessible. I often take a walk to clear my head," she replied, "And Renee knew about my frequent trips there, that's why it wasn't unusual for her when I told her I wanted to show her something in the desert."
  
 

  Paige's love for Renee was well known and she wasn't ready to hide it when asked. "She was special to me, you know. But she never showed up to see what I planned. The next thing I know, she was dead."
  
 

  Feeling he had enough for the moment, Winston decided to end the conversation. Among the many things he had gathered, a fact that stuck to him was the requested flamethrower, seen in Paige's possession a few days ago, was also the murder weapon used in this case, delivered right at Paige's workshop.
  
 

  As Winston was leaving, Paige's gaze followed him. She had a look of a woman caught in a tale of true obsession.
  
 

  Winston parked his car in front of the coffee shop. The afternoon was calm and dry, typical of a day in the desert.
  "David." He called to the barista working behind the counter.
  
 

  "Yes sir, what can I get you?" She looked up with a plastered service smile that Winston had seen more often than he'd like to admit.
  
 

  "Coffee, black," he added.
  
 

  David was usually a woman of few words. It was already known in the café that David, although a people person during work hours, preferred solitude outside of work. She was somewhat enigmatic, leaving work as soon as her shift ended without any explanation about her after-work plans. It was a habit she diligently stuck to, against curious coworkers who often loiter around longer.
  
 

  "Winston, aren't you?" She handed over the coffee, her facial expression gave away nothing. She had a breed of indifference that he found puzzling.
  
 

  "Yeah, you remember." He toasted his coffee cup, looking at the foam art on its surface.
  
 

  Rumor has it that David had been spotted frequenting a local pawn shop on her way from work. Curiously, after one of her visits, a flamethrower was found missing from the shop - the owner had confirmed it himself, ruffling through the shop inventory in disbelief. A particular stock draw from the shop should technically be tagged a coincidence and yet, here he was.
  
 

  "So, how'd you end up here?" Winston decided to put out some line, in search of a bite.
  
 

  "Needed a job, this did me good," she stated curtly, keeping it decidedly professional.
  
 

  "I hear you gotta get fire safety certification to keep the espresso machines running and avoid mishaps. That true?" He ventured further.
  
 

  "Yeah, mandatory stuff." She added, the impenetrable exterior still intact.
  
 

  "That's neat, handy skills I reckon." He sipped his coffee, testing the waters.
  
 

  That's when he remembered the rumors – David had been arrested for a theft charge. Worse yet, she was found guilty and now, a court date next week awaiting sentencing. It all seemed to tie back to an unfortunate event in the desert involving an individual named Renee, who had testified against David in court. Not just a common run-in-the-mill victim, but linked to David with a web of unknown connections.
  
 

  "What time do you get off work?" He asked, catching her off guard.
  
 

  "I...like to go straight home." She fumbled her words. The confession about her arrest seemed to take the wind out of her sails.
  
 

  After a small chat about the dry weather, Winston mentioned he was headed to the pawn shop down the road, on the trail of the missing flamethrower, leaving a hint of a departing farewell. She visibly winced, although she recovered quickly, her unusually bright eyes watched him with a hint of alarm as he walked out.
  
 

  She turned to the wall clock as soon as the shop door jingled shut - the end of her shift almost due. Winston absorbed this behavior, letting his gaze linger for one more moment before setting off.

A lady, Claire as he would come to know, was sitting outside the restaurant in her car. She was shaking, clearly upset, her eyes teary and red.
  
 

  "I suppose you're Claire," Winston guessed, peering through the passenger side window. 
  
 

  "Yes," she sniffed. "I work here and in that place..." she pointed feebly towards the towering construction site in the near distance. "Merely a secretary during the day, and a skilled gardener during my time off, never a scratch from the barbed wire that fences my garden."

  Oddly enough, Amy was seated behind his desk clad in a sharp, well-cut black suit. This wasn't out of character though; this was a man known for appearing overdressed for simple occasions. In fact, a tenant had once mentioned that Amy regularly shops for coats and ties at funeral shops.
  
 

  Winston spotted a shotgun in a corner, a disturbing sight considering it was the same type specified in the coroner's report for Isaac's death. It was an intriguing piece of evidence, considering Amy owns the shotgun.
  
 

  Their conversation veered into various topics, with Amy highlighting his passion for reading. His bookshelf was lined with an extensive collection of books on death rituals from around the world - yet another proof of his peculiar interests. 
  
 

  In the midst of their conversation, Isaac's name came up. Following reliable sources, Winston knew something crucial - Isaac had stumbled upon evidence directly implicating Amy in a tax evasion scheme. Isaac, the ever-vigilant whistleblower, was preparing to expose Amy's scandalous scheme - a revelation that could land Amy in prison.
  
 

  As Winston left the fitness center, he pondered on his findings. Amy's tax evasion scheme, his interest in funeral practices, the shotgun license, the matching murder weapon... it all seemed to connect. He was confident that the tax evasion evidence would be enough to send Amy to jail, but for now, only time would tell. It was just another day on the job for Winston. As for Amy, his fate hung in the balance.
  
 

  Detective Winston studied the scene: shattered glass, blood splatter, and scattered workout equipment telling a silent story. The fitness center wasn't the usual type of crime scene he found himself in. He sighed deeply and headed over to his prime suspect: Alice.
  
 

  Alice was just a stone's throw away from the crime scene. Staring blankly with pale, emotionless eyes. In her hand, a shotgun; paperwork indicating a fresh purchase tucked within its case, valid purchase documents all checked out at the base.
  
 

  Winston approached Alice cautiously and asked, "You know Isaac's workout routine, correct? The list of Isaac's routines you've given us earlier... it matches the information we gathered. You both were here all the time." 
  
 

  Shocked by the sudden personal query, Alice confessed, "We workout together, Winston. At least... we used to."
  
 

  Winston's eyes flickered to the shotgun slackly rested in Alice's lap. "Been a while since I've seen a lady with a new piece like this."
  
 

  Alice was quick to correct him, "Not to boast, Winston, but I've been handling such arms ever since my military days."
  
 

  Despite the grim predicament, Winston could tell Alice was trying to be cooperative. She was calm, composed; despite the whole flare-up. He moved on to the next line of questioning, "Your son... he interacted often with Isaac?"
  
 

  Alice appeared apprehensive before finally admitting, "Recently, yes... He told me Isaac threatened him. Isaac... he acted aggressively towards my boy often."
  
 

  "Interesting," Winston stammered, not wanting to press Alice too hard. He asked a softer question to lighten the mood, "You often workout together then?"
  
 

  Alice looked surprised and retorted mockingly, "Is it that weird? We were the members of the same fitness center after all."
  
 

  Before Winston could continue his questioning, he was handed a document by one of his officers. It read Isaac’s name and the note of a restraining order filed against him by a previous ex-partner. It seemed complicating factors always came in multiples in cases such as this.
  
 

  Without keeping Alice in the dark, he disclosed the information with her, “A restraining order, and a school expulsion due to fighting incidents... Isaac seemed to have some rough patches in the past, huh?”
  
 

  Alice turned her head and acknowledged Winston's statement with a slight nod, her lips sealed shut.
  
 

  Winston wasn't sure why, but he felt the need to reassure her and said, "We're in this together, Alice. We'll figure it out. If Isaac was threatening your son, then we can't overlook any facet of the situation."
  
 

  Seeing Alice with a newly purchased shotgun in her possession and catching onto bits of their relationship, Winston tried to figure out the puzzle, leaving no stone unturned. The interview with Alice wasn't offering any easy solutions, but Winston knew the case was anything but such.
